title: Valtteri Bottas wins F1 Japanese Grand Prix, with Lewis Hamilton third
text:
Advertisement

Lewis Hamilton was denied victory at the Japanese Grand Prix that survived the typhoon by a rare mistake by all-conquering Mercedes.

The race was instead won under blue skies by his team-mate Valtteri Bottas – a one-three finish that secured the constructors’ title for the Brackley-based outfit for a record sixth consecutive time.

Sebastian Vettel, who seemed lucky to escape punishment for an apparent jumped start from pole, was second for Ferrari.

Valtteri Bottas celebrates on the podium after winning the Japanese Grand Prix at Suzuka for his third triumph of the year

Team-mate Lewis Hamilton was left a disgruntled third after Mercedes blundered in giving him a weak pit strategy

Sebastian Vettel took second for Ferrari as all three drivers salute the crowd from on top of the podium

The result of the race meant Mercedes secured both the constructors' and drivers' championships for a sixth season running

Bottas's victory was also his first since winning the Azerbaijan Grand Prix in Baku back in April at the fourth race of the year

Hamilton had hoped to make it a fifth win for him at Suzuka and it looked as if it might just be on when he was reshod on medium tyres on lap 21 of 53.. The new rubber was meant to last him the remainder of the race. But they did not and he came in a second time, plunging him from first to third place.

Bottas, on a more clinical two-stop strategy by design, swept to his third win of the season.

Hamilton questioned his strategy straight after his first stop.

His race engineer Peter Bonnington told him: ‘So you’re currently P3. Vettel 10 seconds ahead. Deg looks very high, so one stop will be a struggle. Let’s chase Vettel down.’

Bottas controlled the race from start to finish to take an easy win for Mercedes following another error strewn day from Ferrari

Ferrari drivers Vettel and Charles Leclerc share a discussion post race following another poor display from the team

Vettel reflects on what could have been after his near false start played a big part in Ferrari losing the race

Vettel hesitated on the line and it allowed Bottas to easily pass him on the run down into the first corner

Vettel managed to hold onto second place but came under fire from Leclerc, Hamilton (left) and Max Verstappen (right)

Verstappen's storming start for Red Bull saw him make a pass around the outside of Leclerc into turn one

But Verstappen tangled with Leclerc who appeared to barge the Dutchman off the race circuit as fans look on from the stands

Verstappen dropped down to 17th as a result but he picked up too much damage from the incident and retired soon after

Hamilton replied: ‘Valtteri, how far?’

PB: ‘Valtteri’s nearly got a full pit stop.’

LH: ‘How have I lost that much time?’

PB: ‘Deg is much higher, deg is much higher. And we lost time behind Vettel.’

LH: ‘I’m out of the race now. If deg is that massive why didn’t you give me hard tyres? Can you guys explain a bit please. I’m basically out of the race with a pitstop behind.’

Leclerc collected a broken endplate on his front wing, forcing him into an early pit-stop and ruining his race

Vettel managed to hold onto second despite late pressure from Hamilton but it was not enough to deny Mercedes the titles

PB: ‘So Vettel is guaranteed a two-stop, so we can see how this comes to us.’

It didn’t. Hamilton was in again on lap 42. He tried to hunt down Vettel and was all over the German in the closing stages but he couldn’t quite blast past.

It was a three-car fight after Charle Leclerc pranged his Ferrari into Max Verstappen on the first lap. Leclerc finished sixth but Verstappen retired.

Hamilton, who set the fastest lap, now needs to score 14 points more than Bottas in Mexico City in a fortnight. Otherwise, it goes down to the US, with Brazil and Abu Dhabi after that.

London-born Thai Alex Albon was fourth for Red Bull, his best finish.

In the sole remaining Red Bull Alex Albon took a career high fourth place as he tackles the S-curves early in the lap

McLaren also enjoyed a strong afternoon with Carlos Sainz who took fifth place for the Woking based outfit

By contrast, British team-mate Lando Norris endured a torrid afternoon and ended up finishing 13th

Drivers tackle the uphill hairpin at the start of the race at Suzuka which was bathed in sunshine following the typhoon
description: JONATHAN McEVOY AT SUZUKA: Lewis Hamilton was denied victory at the Japanese Grand Prix that survived the typhoon by a rare mistake by all-conquering Mercedes.
